description: This program supports the Mission's goal for an independent, prosperous, and healthy Ukraine united around core European values in one or more of the following sectors: strengthening of democratic governance, and more inclusive, sustainable, market-driven economic growth.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: : Poltava Trolleybus
description: The provision of a € 10 million loan to Municipal Enterprise  'Poltavaelectroavtotrans' (the "Company") to finance (i) the acquisition of up  to 40 new trolleybuses and related maintenance and diagnostic equipment, (ii)  modernisation of three substations.  The Project is part of the proposed a € 250 million Ukraine Public Transport  Framework II consisting of municipal-guaranteed loans to public transport  companies in Ukraine to facilitate critical improvements in public transport  infrastructure in a number of cities across Ukraine.  The Project will address critical challenges, including, inter alia, air  pollution, quality of public transport services and infrastructure in urban  transport development of the City of Poltava by improving both the access to  clean urban transport, as well as the capacity and efficiency of public  transport services.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Ukrenergo Transmission Network Modernisation
description: The provision of a sovereign-guaranteed loan to the National Energy Company  Ukrenergo ("Ukrenergo" or the "Company") of up to EUR 149 million, EUR 147.2 of  which has been repurposed into emergency liquidity to support the Company and  ensure stable and uninterrupted electricity transmission services on the entire  territory of Ukraine despite the devastating impact of Russian war on Ukraine  (the "Project"). The EBRD loan is also backed by the EU EFSD guarantee and the  UK Government sovereign donor guarantee.  The Project will safeguard electricity provision and access to vital services  for people and businesses, whose livelihoods and economic security is at  immense risk due to Russian war on Ukraine.
sector_code: Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)

reporting: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)
title: Integrated Urban Development in Ukraine II
description: The framework conditions for the implementation of integrated urban development policy have been improved according to the principles of the Leipzig Charter, the Agenda 2030 and the Paris Climate Agreement at national level and in selected cities.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Ukreximbank Loan for RE/EE Financing
description: The increase of the EBRD's exposure by EUR 8.6 million ("B Loan" outstanding  principal) under the existing A/B senior loan for renewable energy and energy  efficiency (RE/EE) financing (the "Loan") in favour of JSC "The State  Export-Import Bank of Ukraine" ("Ukreximbank").   The Loan was originally approved by the Board on 19 June 2019 and signed on  16 August 2019 in the total amount of EUR 80 million, out of which EUR 40  million was syndicated and EUR 40 million taken by EBRD.  syndicated and EUR40 million taken by EBRD. title: Development of Ukraine's new Subsoil Code, Ukraine
description: The overall objective of the project is to support the implementation of reforms in Ukraine's extractive sector by harmonising Ukraines subsoil legislation in line with the best practices in the EU Member States and where relevant in line with EU acquis.  The project is designed to support the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of Ukraine in the implementation of reforms of the Ukrainian extractive sector. The assistance will be focused on putting in place a new subsoil use system in l

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: LDC Rail Ukraine
description: The provision of a US$ 35 million senior loan to finance the acquisition of up  to 1,000 grain hopper railcars by a subsidiary of Louis Dreyfus Company in  Ukraine.  The Project will support the client's strategy of building a reliable and  efficient supply chain in Ukraine and will aim to address the existing shortage  of railcars on the Ukrainian market.

title: SWIFT 5
description: Will provide support to countries in political transition with rapid and effective technical assistance for positive political change. This multi-award contract is the fifth iteration of the SWIFT IDIQ, with a five-year period of performance and a ceiling of $2.5 billion. This IDIQ is designed to establish, staff, manage, operate, and support a flexible, quick response mechanism capable of administering and implementing targeted activities under OTI Country or Regional Programs; and, b) provide support to program-funded personnel.
sector_code: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Ukraine Railway Eurobonds
description: The investment of up to US$ 100 million in a tap issue of Ukrainian Railways  PJSC ("UZ" or the "Company") senior unsecured Eurobonds. The Eurobonds tap is  structured as an issuance of loan participation notes carried out by a Special  Purpose Vehicle, Rail Capital Markets PLC (the "Issuer"), and is a follow up to  the initial public issuance of US$ 500 million that took place on 1 July 2019.  The proceeds from the Bank's financing will be used to finance the  rehabilitation of priority railway lines.  The proceeds will be used to finance the rehabilitation of railway tracks  (predominantly on the Trans-European Transport Network corridors within  Ukraine), with a focus on priority sections which are currently limiting the  operational speed of trains. The rehabilitation will allow to increase the  speed of trains, overal throughput capacity, and reduce CO2 emissions. Thew  Project will benefit from the introduction of the EBRD's procurement rules,  Environmental and Social Policy and the implementation of a Corporate  Governance Action Plan for UZ's subsidiaries.

reporting: European Commission - DG Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations
title: Support for the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement Phase II
description: The project aims to effectively raise Ukrainian public authorities' capacities in designing and implementing key reforms stemming from the Association Agreement/DCFTA.The purposes of this contract are as follows:purpose 1: To facilitate the legal approximation processes linked to the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement (AA) implementation.purpose 2: To improve efficient communication of government authorities of central and regional levels to ensure support to EUI/AA reforms.

title: Trade and market intelligence for the Eastern Partnership Countries
description: The Eastern Area Partnership (EaP) Helpdesk will provide economic operators, particularly small and medium enterprises (SMEs), trade and investment support institutions (TISIs) and policy makers in EaP countries with an interactive online platform that offers access to trade information (e.g. tariffs, non-tariff measures, taxes, trade statistics, trade procedures and company data) necessary to do business in the region and with the European Union (EU). An online feedback mechanism will allow companies to report on difficulties they face in international trade. Surveys of trade barriers in each country will enable an increased understanding of the regulatory and procedural obstacles that companies face and help policy makers to identify options to reduce trade costs. Training on the analysis of the information available via the Helpdesk will allow SMEs and TISIs to identify export opportunities and the capacity of institutions to collect and process services data for selected sectors will be be strengthened.

title: ProCredit Bank Ukraine SME LCY Loan
description: The increase by US$3 million the Bank's existing local currency loan agreement  with JSC ProCredit Bank (Ukraine) from 2019 (the increased total loan amount  will be US$25 million in UAH equivalent). The proceeds will be used to finance  SMEs under the EBRD Financial Intermediaries Framework (FIF)  The Loan proceeds will be used for on-lending to private micro-, small and  medium sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Ukraine. The Project will help to (i)  support the Bank's client and an established market leader in SME lending in  Ukraine; (ii) facilitate the bank's SME business growth; and (iii) diversify  and strengthen bank's funding structure with medium-term local currency  resources.

title: SALAR/SKR: Support decentralization in Ukraine Phase II
description:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19
Swedish Association of Local Authorities and Regions (SALAR) has applied to Sida for funding of 41 710 000 SEK to carry out the "Support Decentralization in Ukraine Phase II Programme" in Ukraine during the activity period 2020 - 2022. 

The intervention aims at strengthening democracy, improving governance and better service delivery to the citizens of Ukraine (women, men, boys and girls) by 

1)  supporting the Ministry of Education of Ukraine to implement improvements to the formula for allocating education grants (subventions) to sub-national governments by building the Ministry’s capacities in data collection, analysis and evidence-based decision-making (including transparency, openness, accountability, participation, fairness (non-discriminatory) and gender-responsiveness); 

2) increasing capacity of the relevant state institutions (in particular Ministry of Community Development and Territories and Ministry of Finance) to analyze the financial data and use the financial data and analytics to inform policy; 

3) supporting the Association of Amalgamated communities to become a stronger advocate for the interests of local communities and 

4) providing relevant Parliamentary committees with important insights and knowledge particularly as it relates to issues of legislative processes, dialogue, transparency, accountability and gender responsiveness. The intervention builds upon the results and lessons of previous 5 years programme on the support to the reform of local self-governance in Ukraine.

The intervention’s total budget is 41 710 000 SEK, out of which approximately 900 000 SEK will be allocated for the programme evaluation (to be procured by the cooperation partner). Sida will be the only funder of the intervention.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Green for Growth Fund: A-Shares
description: The proposed transaction is a re-investment of up to EUR 20 million in senior  A-class shares of GGF.  The proceeds of EBRD's investment will be used for on-lending to financial and  non-financial partner institutions ("PIs") in accordance with the Fund's  investment guidelines. The loans to PIs are in the form of senior debt,  subordinated debt and guarantees, and aim to fund Energy Efficiency ("EE"),  Resource Efficiency ("RE") and renewable energy projects across the Fund's  target region, including Southeast Europe, the East and South European  Neighbourhood Region ("ENR").

The loans to PIs are in the form of senior debt,  subordinated debt and guarantees, and aim to fund Energy Efficiency ("EE"),  Resource Efficiency ("RE") and renewable energy projects across the Fund's  target region, including Southeast Europe, the East and South European  Neighbourhood Region ("ENR").

reporting: European Commission - DG Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations
title: Enhancement of educational and scientific role of DonNUET as an internally displaced higher education institution in Donetsk region community
description: Action will support:upgrade of curricula,  improvement of  quality of education and DonNUET management system; renovation of Mariupol College of DonNUET and  Sviatohirsk facility of DonNUET;  and provide new services for students, staff and local community; strengthen the role of student self-government

reporting: European Commission - DG Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations
title: Intensification of influence of teachers of Luhansk region on the processes of reconciliation and peace-building
description: Promote peace and reconciliation in the East of Ukraine by reinforcing the capacity of Luhansk Taras Shevchenko National University and Luhansk Regional In-Service Teacher Training Institute through strengthening of network of resource centers for Luhansk region teachers, upgrading university infrastructure, improving conditions for university staff, and further developing student services, including student self-governance

reporting: European Commission - DG Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations
title: Ukraine Municipal Transport and Investment Programme
description: The UMIP Project is a multi-sector programme targeting public infrastructure projects in the following sectors: energy efficiency (district heating, municipal lighting), water supply, wastewater and solid waste management. The objective of the UMIP Project is to rehabilitate and upgrade the municipal infrastructure in Ukraine by substantially improving energy efficiency and thus contributing to Ukraines energy security. Furthermore, the upgrades are expected to result in reduction in water lo

reporting: European Commission - DG Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations
title: TransparentCities e-platform for cooperation of citizens and local governments for accountability and good governance
description: The Action will strive to achieve the following objectives: 1. Empower a coalition of 20 CSOs to assess accountability and governance practices in 14 areas at 50 cities through the innovative TransparentCities e-platform.2. Foster the development of 30 cities through supporting cooperation with civil society, usage of accountability tools and replication of best initiatives from other cities.3. Engage citizens and activists in 50 cities to participate in the promotion of good governance.

title: Organizational transformation of the national public broadcaster in Ukraine
description:
NPBU formulated Project objectives as follows:
1) Completed transition from manual management (micromanagement) to process management (through goals and workflows)
2) Launch of automated workflows at UA:PBC 
3) Transformed corporate culture compliant with UA:PBC’s values and mission 
4) UA:PBC becomes a reliable and more reputable source of information by using information on public opinion.
Effectiveness and competitiveness of a media company is based on a proper functioning of 3 main pillars: people, management system and content (see the chart below).

UA:PBC faces big challenges in every of these spheres, namely:
1) Management system: Following the drastic downsizing, the company is revising its internal structure and management system in accordance with international management principles and current best international practices at broadcasting companies. As of now, there is manual management in a company. Management team members have different views on the framework for building a business process/management system. Business processes of the company are not defined or regulated. For 26 years, the company had been state owned and consisted of 31 independent companies which were united only in 2017. The most widespread tools at the company are still Excel and Google documents. Data is stored in different formats and is not interrelated. The management needs to wait for reports or entry data relevant for management decision-making from two hours to several days. All this is exacerbated by inflated number of staff, excessive and obsolete bureaucracy, poor confidentiality of information, inefficient use of resources and limited information for management decisions.
2) Human resources:UA:PBC inherited corporate culture, which is typical for a dependent and controlled state institution and is inconsistent with the current values of the company. This culture has been hampering changes and demotivating the best staff.
3) Content:The old system of state television was oriented at the government and focused on the interests of officials. To work for the benefit of the people and be a source of credible and truthful information about society UA: PBC needs effective tools to measure public opinion. Currently, the company does not have such tools and decisions what content to produce are taken without having sufficient evidence-based information. This significantly influences the quality and format of the content as well as the ways of its distribution.Becoming an effective company is possible only after solving all the above-mentioned challenges, i.e. full transformation of UA:PBC’s management system, corporate culture and change of content production approaches.These needs for changes are the basis for the implementation of UA:PBC's development Strategy for 2020-2022. Four vectors of transformation were chosen for implementation of this Strategy: organizational, technological, content transformation and transformation of corporate culture. Project’s outcomes cover an important part of the success factors that must be achieved in all transformation vectors.
There is a good common ground, joint understanding and commitment of the key stakeholders to work on organizational, digital, and corporate culture transformations as well as on enhancing audience outreach and engagement. The plan for this intervention is to make a concentrated effort to conduct full organizational transformation of the public service media system in Ukraine.
Theory of changeThe following objectives are proposed:Development objective: Effective and competitive public service broadcaster in Ukraine as a tool for democracy and empowerment.Project objective: Transformed management system, corporate culture and approaches to content production of public service broadcaster in Ukraine
The draft Result-based management (RBM) matrix for the project puts forward four outcomes and several outputs. The proposed outcomes are closely interlinked and causal relations can be traced in the programme document. Workflow automation is impossible without transition to system management. Transformation of corporate culture should be strengthened by providing appropriate tools for staff, namely clear “rules of game” (workflows); and IT systems for implementing these rules. The cooperation partner plans to finalize the RBM Matrix with realistic numbers added at the output, activities and indicators level after the inception period, as soon as the procured consultants for each component process the results of their initial diagnostics and audits. The application of RBM matrix as a steering tool implies regular follow up and adjustments to stay on track and reach the intended results.
The Embassy assesses this as a feasible plan. However, the cooperation partner obviously lacks RBM application knowledge, e.g. separate "theories of change" were suggested for every component of the project, but an umbrella vision has not been framed properly in the respective section of the proposal, even though it can be elicited from the programme document in its other parts. The Embassy suggests additional RBM training for the staff of this cooperation partner during the inception phase of the project, preferably the one organized by Sida Partnership Forum. 
Project contentFull organizational transformation will take time and considerable effort. Therefore, the Embassy assesses  that a proposed project time span of three years will be necessary to conduct the transformation. Detailed project outcomes, outputs, activities, baselines, indicators and time frame are described in the draft RBM matrix.
Outcome 1. Conducted transition from manual management (micromanagement) to process management (through goals and workflows)UA:PBC’s goal is to transform the existing management system to a fundamentally new level, focused on efficiency, clarity and transparency. The evolution of the transformation of UA:PBC’s management system can be seen in the chart below. Currently, UA:PBC aims to make a transition to process management.
Evolution of the transformation of the management system:Process management is a management approach in which a company is viewed as a network of interconnected business processes rather than distinct functions, as opposed to a functional approach. The advantage of process management is its focus on the end result of each individual business process, which is a sequence of operations, and set of processes. Process approach allows evaluating the contribution of each business process to the end result of the company’s activities, which triggers positive effect for employees’ motivation. Optimization of business processes will contribute to the company's sustainable opreation as an independent and effective institution.More than 20% of the Roadmap's recommendations are devoted to the design of business processes and are included in this project. Their implementation is one of the most complex and largest tasks, since it concerns almost the entire company and will have noticeable impact. Processes will be not only described but also optimized showing how to use employees’ time more effectively. This can lead to the improvement of organization’s structure and, hence, to optimization of human resources. It also foresees the reduction of the level of bureaucracy as well as effective distribution of authority. Launch of the process approach will reduce timeframes of decision-making as well as enhance decision-making efficiency. This will all also lead to savings of financial resources.
Outcome 2. Automated workflowsDigital transformation involves creating databases, developing products, automatization of business processes, integration of accounting financial and personnel systems of the central directorate and branches into a single system, and developing a cross-cutting analytics system that will enhance the company’s efficiency.The chart below shows how single information space should look like:
Automatization would enable optimization of human and financial resources and increase of transparency of financial and personnel processes. Since single information storage is envisioned in this system, the reliability and confidentiality of information would increase. As a result, NPBU's would stregthen its competitiveness and improve its image as a modern innovative institution. Technological changes will affect all the staff and will lead to significant improvement of the quality of financial and personnel services. Employees will also have a platform for internal communication, which increases openness. The company will be fully digitalized.
Outcome 3. Transformed corporate culture fitting UA:PBC’s values and missionFormation and development of the corporate culture is an important task and a prerequisite for the effective implementation of changes at UA:PBC and its sustainable development.The external influence of the organization is directly related to its internal integrity and ideology. That is why the internal culture of the public broadcaster must be as consistent as possible and not only contribute to the effectiveness of the organization itself, but also to the strengthening of UA:PBC’s position and its role in the formation of national consciousness. Corporate culture also creates employees’ engagement and is a key to managing the organization.UA:PBC’s goal is to create the desired vision of the organization’s culture in order to achieve an influential position of UA:PBC outside and have attractive image as an employer inside and outside as well as to set up HR system so that the desired organization culture is built up as efficiently as possible.After the transformation of corporate culture employees’ engagement, motivation, loyalty as well as efficiency will significantly increase, managers at any level will understand where and how the company changes and what is required from them. This will also increase the speed of internal communication as well as its quality.
Outcome 4. UA: PBC becomes a reputable source of information by using public opinion trendsUA:PBC needs to know exactly what is bothering Ukrainians and discuss these issues. This is a fundamental function of the public service broadcaster, a key component of the brand and its reputation.By establishing a well-functioning and innovative marketing department, UA:PBC will be able to:• get quick public opinion on current issues;• systematically cooperate with experts who generate issues that need actualization in society;• discuss all current issues and topics on the air and create socially important content;• disseminate the received data in the country's information space.The products' menu should include analytics, data, metrics, ratings, value orientations which will be used internally by program director, producers, editors, PR department, Management Board and externally by leaders of public opinion, mass media, think tanks, and public authorities.A well functioning and innovative marketing department will be able to help NPBU shape the social agenda, produce annual reports on social trends and set standards. At the internal level UA:PBC will be able to control the achievement of its marketing goals, generate evidence-based themes for the creative team, study regional audiences and their needs.

UA:PBC faces big challenges in every of these spheres, namely:
1) Management system: Following the drastic downsizing, the company is revising its internal structure and management system in accordance with international management principles and current best international practices at broadcasting companies. As of now, there is manual management in a company. Management team members have different views on the framework for building a business process/management system. Business processes of the company are not defined or regulated. For 26 years, the company had been state owned and consisted of 31 independent companies which were united only in 2017. The most widespread tools at the company are still Excel and Google documents. Data is stored in different formats and is not interrelated. The management needs to wait for reports or entry data relevant for management decision-making from two hours to several days. All this is exacerbated by inflated number of staff, excessive and obsolete bureaucracy, poor confidentiality of information, inefficient use of resources and limited information for management decisions.
2) Human resources:UA:PBC inherited corporate culture, which is typical for a dependent and controlled state institution and is inconsistent with the current values of the company. This culture has been hampering changes and demotivating the best staff.
3) Content:The old system of state television was oriented at the government and focused on the interests of officials. To work for the benefit of the people and be a source of credible and truthful information about society UA: PBC needs effective tools to measure public opinion. Currently, the company does not have such tools and decisions what content to produce are taken without having sufficient evidence-based information. This significantly influences the quality and format of the content as well as the ways of its distribution.Becoming an effective company is possible only after solving all the above-mentioned challenges, i.e. full transformation of UA:PBC’s management system, corporate culture and change of content production approaches.These needs for changes are the basis for the implementation of UA:PBC's development Strategy for 2020-2022. Four vectors of transformation were chosen for implementation of this Strategy: organizational, technological, content transformation and transformation of corporate culture. Project’s outcomes cover an important part of the success factors that must be achieved in all transformation vectors.
There is a good common ground, joint understanding and commitment of the key stakeholders to work on organizational, digital, and corporate culture transformations as well as on enhancing audience outreach and engagement. The plan for this intervention is to make a concentrated effort to conduct full organizational transformation of the public service media system in Ukraine.
Theory of changeThe following objectives are proposed:Development objective: Effective and competitive public service broadcaster in Ukraine as a tool for democracy and empowerment.Project objective: Transformed management system, corporate culture and approaches to content production of public service broadcaster in Ukraine
The draft Result-based management (RBM) matrix for the project puts forward four outcomes and several outputs. The proposed outcomes are closely interlinked and causal relations can be traced in the programme document. Workflow automation is impossible without transition to system management. Transformation of corporate culture should be strengthened by providing appropriate tools for staff, namely clear “rules of game” (workflows); and IT systems for implementing these rules. The cooperation partner plans to finalize the RBM Matrix with realistic numbers added at the output, activities and indicators level after the inception period, as soon as the procured consultants for each component process the results of their initial diagnostics and audits. The application of RBM matrix as a steering tool implies regular follow up and adjustments to stay on track and reach the intended results.
The Embassy assesses this as a feasible plan. However, the cooperation partner obviously lacks RBM application knowledge, e.g. separate "theories of change" were suggested for every component of the project, but an umbrella vision has not been framed properly in the respective section of the proposal, even though it can be elicited from the programme document in its other parts. The Embassy suggests additional RBM training for the staff of this cooperation partner during the inception phase of the project, preferably the one organized by Sida Partnership Forum. 
Project contentFull organizational transformation will take time and considerable effort. Therefore, the Embassy assesses  that a proposed project time span of three years will be necessary to conduct the transformation. Detailed project outcomes, outputs, activities, baselines, indicators and time frame are described in the draft RBM matrix.
Outcome 1. Conducted transition from manual management (micromanagement) to process management (through goals and workflows)UA:PBC’s goal is to transform the existing management system to a fundamentally new level, focused on efficiency, clarity and transparency. The evolution of the transformation of UA:PBC’s management system can be seen in the chart below. Currently, UA:PBC aims to make a transition to process management.
Evolution of the transformation of the management system:Process management is a management approach in which a company is viewed as a network of interconnected business processes rather than distinct functions, as opposed to a functional approach. The advantage of process management is its focus on the end result of each individual business process, which is a sequence of operations, and set of processes. Process approach allows evaluating the contribution of each business process to the end result of the company’s activities, which triggers positive effect for employees’ motivation. Optimization of business processes will contribute to the company's sustainable opreation as an independent and effective institution.More than 20% of the Roadmap's recommendations are devoted to the design of business processes and are included in this project. Their implementation is one of the most complex and largest tasks, since it concerns almost the entire company and will have noticeable impact. Processes will be not only described but also optimized showing how to use employees’ time more effectively. This can lead to the improvement of organization’s structure and, hence, to optimization of human resources. It also foresees the reduction of the level of bureaucracy as well as effective distribution of authority. Launch of the process approach will reduce timeframes of decision-making as well as enhance decision-making efficiency. This will all also lead to savings of financial resources.
Outcome 2. Automated workflowsDigital transformation involves creating databases, developing products, automatization of business processes, integration of accounting financial and personnel systems of the central directorate and branches into a single system, and developing a cross-cutting analytics system that will enhance the company’s efficiency.The chart below shows how single information space should look like:
Automatization would enable optimization of human and financial resources and increase of transparency of financial and personnel processes. Since single information storage is envisioned in this system, the reliability and confidentiality of information would increase. As a result, NPBU's would stregthen its competitiveness and improve its image as a modern innovative institution. Technological changes will affect all the staff and will lead to significant improvement of the quality of financial and personnel services. Employees will also have a platform for internal communication, which increases openness. The company will be fully digitalized.
Outcome 3. Transformed corporate culture fitting UA:PBC’s values and missionFormation and development of the corporate culture is an important task and a prerequisite for the effective implementation of changes at UA:PBC and its sustainable development.The external influence of the organization is directly related to its internal integrity and ideology. That is why the internal culture of the public broadcaster must be as consistent as possible and not only contribute to the effectiveness of the organization itself, but also to the strengthening of UA:PBC’s position and its role in the formation of national consciousness. Corporate culture also creates employees’ engagement and is a key to managing the organization.UA:PBC’s goal is to create the desired vision of the organization’s culture in order to achieve an influential position of UA:PBC outside and have attractive image as an employer inside and outside as well as to set up HR system so that the desired organization culture is built up as efficiently as possible.After the transformation of corporate culture employees’ engagement, motivation, loyalty as well as efficiency will significantly increase, managers at any level will understand where and how the company changes and what is required from them. This will also increase the speed of internal communication as well as its quality.
Outcome 4. UA: PBC becomes a reputable source of information by using public opinion trendsUA:PBC needs to know exactly what is bothering Ukrainians and discuss these issues. This is a fundamental function of the public service broadcaster, a key component of the brand and its reputation.By establishing a well-functioning and innovative marketing department, UA:PBC will be able to:• get quick public opinion on current issues;• systematically cooperate with experts who generate issues that need actualization in society;• discuss all current issues and topics on the air and create socially important content;• disseminate the received data in the country's information space.The products' menu should include analytics, data, metrics, ratings, value orientations which will be used internally by program director, producers, editors, PR department, Management Board and externally by leaders of public opinion, mass media, think tanks, and public authorities.A well functioning and innovative marketing department will be able to help NPBU shape the social agenda, produce annual reports on social trends and set standards. At the internal level UA:PBC will be able to control the achievement of its marketing goals, generate evidence-based themes for the creative team, study regional audiences and their needs.

title: COVID-19 HelpAge 2020-2024
description: By 2030, millions of older people will enjoy a better quality of life, through improved wellbeing, enhanced dignity and greater voice. In order to achieve this, HelpAge International will prioritize 10 focus areas:1. Inspire a movement for change- Supporting older people and civil society to unite and demand change, mobilising a peoples movement for a fairer world for everyone to grow old in, promoting older peoples rights and transforming the way people think, feel and act on ageing.2. Create a society for all ages- Promoting inclusive environments and communities integrating all ages, where older people feel connected and can participate equally as they wish.3. Improve income security-Protecting older peoples independence and Sense of purpose by promoting social pensions, access to decent work, economic opportunities and financial services without discrimination.4. Promote age-inclusive systems- Calling for and securing ratification of age inclusive laws, policies and systems to guarantee older peoples rights across all sectors, tracking implementation and holding actors to account.5. Support healthy ageing- Supporting the transformation of systems to promote healthy ageing, including the implementation of inclusive universal health coverage and long-term care and support systems.6. Deliver inclusive humanitarian action-Promoting age-inclusive humanitarian preparedness and response to ensure older people are protected, feel safe and have full access to assistance.7. Challenge violence, abuse and neglect- Exposing the risks of violence, abuse and neglect older people face, with a particular focus on older women, and work with others to take action.8. Take a stand against ageism- Taking a stand against ageism, engaging all stakeholders including duty bearers, the wider community and older people themselves. It will promote positive attitudes and behavior towards older people, ensuring their contribution is valued and they are treated fairly and with respect.9. Embrace technology- Advocating for older people to receive maximum benefit and minimum harm from technological change in all sectors of society.10. Foster lifelong learning- Promoting access to lifelong learning, professional and personal opportunities, as well as other educational opportunities so that older people develop their full potential to participate in society.Complementary to the Core Activities, this contribution supports HelpAge's  Global COVID-19 Response Plan so that older people are protected by reducing their exposure to COVID-19 through age inclusive preparedness, response and recovery.In March 2022 an agreement amendment was decided for support to older and disabled people in Ukraine and refugees in Moldova with NFI, health and mental health  and psycho social support.

title: Core funding to support delivery of Frontline AIDS' Global Plan of Action
description:
- Speak truth: Our global and national engagement will galvanise urgent action on AIDS, particularly around the crisis in HIV prevention.
- Unlock barriers: Our advocacy with communities will challenge social and gender norms and influence governments and other institutions to develop and implement laws, plans and policies to ensure full access to services.
- Invest in solutions: We will tailor our innovative solutions to respond to the needs of the most marginalised people.
- Build a sustainable future: Our technical assistance for civil society and governments will enhance the delivery, governance and monitoring of comprehensive national HIV responses.

title: Informing Policy through strengthening national, regional and global data and indicator frameworks and integrated analysis on the environmental dimension of the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs
description:
Informing Policy through strengthening national, regional and global data and indicator frameworks on the environmental dimension of the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs and developing methodologies for integrated analysis

The importance of improving the availability of and access to data and statistics related to the environment was recognized through the adoption of a wide range of environmentally Sustainable Development Goals, targets and indicators. The ‘Measuring Progress Report (UNEP, 2019) found that of the 93 environment-related SDGs indicators, 68 per cent lack sufficient data to assess progress.
UN Environment is the custodian agency for 26 core environment indicators for Goals 6, 8, 12, 14, 15, and 17 in the global framework for the 2030 Agenda.  General Assembly Resolution A/RES/71/313 on Work of the Statistical Commission pertaining to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development states the role of Custodian Agencies as (1) providing the methodologies used to harmonize country data for international comparability and produce estimates through transparent mechanisms, and (2) supporting the strengthening of data collection and statistical capacity-building, including capacity-building that strengthens coordination among national statistical offices, as appropriate and within their mandates, in a coordinated manner that recognizes national priorities and reflects national ownership of the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
The project contributes to the objective for the Environment under Review Sub-programme that “By 2030, Governments and other stakeholders use quality open environmental data, analyses and participatory processes that strengthen the science-policy interface (e.g. GEO, SDG, CoPs) to generate evidence-based environmental assessments, identify emerging issues and foster policy action”.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: DCFTA - OTP Leasing SME Facility #3
description: A 4-year amortising senior unsecured loan of up to €15 million equivalent to be  provided to LLC "OTP Leasing" for on-lending to eligible MSMEs under the DCFTA  Programme (known asEU4BUSINESS EBRD Credit Line - Finance and Advisory  Programme Supporting SME). The loan will be available for disbursement as a  synthetic UAH and/or €-denominated facility.  The project will enable the Company to finance long-term investments of  Ukrainian MSMEs in upgrading their technology and equipment necessary to meet  EU standards in terms of product quality, health and safety measures and  environmental preservation.

title: Internally Displaced Person (IDP) Housing
description: The overall objective of the project is to contribute to the Government of Ukraine's efforts to improve housing conditions of internally displaced persons (IDPs) by increasing the opportunities and options to access to housing. The project is primarily focused on Donetsk and Luhansk regions to provide long-term housing solutions for IDPs affected by the conflict in Ukraine.

reporting: Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)
title: Housing for internally displaced persons (IOM/ISP)
description: The project "Housing for Internally Displaced Persons (IOM/ISP)" aims to create needs-based and affordable housing for internally displaced persons in Ukraine. The Russian war of aggression on Ukraine has triggered one of the biggest humanitarian crises ever and escalated the already difficult housing situation. The number of people displaced from their homes is currently estimated at over 13.2 million. Of these, more than 6.6 million have fled to neighbouring countries and another 6.6 million within Ukraine, according to UNHCR. As a result, communities estimate that more than 10% of IDPs will remain long-term or permanently in their place of displacement, where host communities are stretched to their limits in providing sustainable shelter for IDPs. This project aims to increase the number of usable homes and the number of potential applications for these homes. This will be done, inter alia, through new construction, reconstruction or repair of buildings and an increase of the capacity of the Ukrainian government and local authorities. In the process, protection against sexual exploitation and abuse is to be ensured by providing special training to local partners and staff, and by providing beneficiaries with extensive information about their rights and the relevant complaints bodies.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: DCFTA - Bank Lviv SME Facility
description: A 4-year amortising senior unsecured loan of up to € 7.5 million to be provided  to JSC Joint Stock Bank "Lviv" for on-lending to eligible MSMEs under the DCFTA  Programme, (known as EU4BUSINESS EBRD Credit Line - Finance and Advisory  Programme Supporting SME). The loan will be available for disbursement as a  synthetic UAH facility.  The proposed project will enable the participating financial institution to  finance sub-loans under the Programme, supporting investments of Ukrainian  MSMEs in upgrading their technology and equipment necessary to meet EU  standards in terms of product quality, health and safety measures and  environmental preservation. Sub-borrowers will benefit from financial  incentives for eligible sub-projects, while Bank Lviv will receive technical  assistance from the Programme dedicated consultants towards investment projects  preparation and implementation.

title: Sustainable Bioenergy Value Chain Innovations
description: Normal   0               21         false   false   false      EN-US   X-NONE   X-NONE                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  /* Style Definitions */  table.MsoNormalTable  {mso-style-name:"Table Normal";  mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;  mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;  mso-style-noshow:yes;  mso-style-priority:99;  mso-style-parent:"";  mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;  mso-para-margin:0cm;  mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;  mso-pagination:widow-orphan;  font-size:10.0pt;  font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;  mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";  mso-ansi-language:EN-US;  mso-fareast-language:EN-US;}    The Project is anticipated to produce a range of co-benefits. Consistent with the EBRD’s mandate to support transition, the Project will offer significant socioeconomic benefits across the country, including those associated with resource savings and efficiency gains by replacing fossil fuels with sustainable biomass. These will contribute to increasing the competitiveness of local agribusiness and assist in future-proofing these climate change risks through both investments in sustainable agribusiness and awareness raising.  By focusing on waste utilisation, the Project will provide various benefits for the local private agricultural sector. It will focus on adding value to production residues which will be processed through sustainable energy production systems and thus decrease environmental pressure and reduce GHG emissions.  The Project has significant potential in adding to the overall country’s energy security. As noted throughout the document, Ukraine has massive energy potential embedded in its agribiomass and the Project will assist the country in moving towards energy independence through utilisation of its sustainable local resources.
sector_code: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

title: Good Governance Fund: Lot 2A - Technical Assistance Facility, Eastern Partnership
description: The UK Good Governance Fund (GGF) is a programme portfolio delivered by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO), which provides technical assistance and capacity building support in beneficiary countries. The Technical Assistance Facility: Eastern Partnership (TAF-EP) delivers responsive and demand-led support to the governments of Armenia, Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova. The core objectives of the TAF-EP are to provide beneficiaries with rapid access to high-quality technical expertise which builds domestic capacity; deliver a flexible and mixed portfolio of projects; and bring together international technical expertise and best-practice with a strong understanding of local need and context. Projects include support for domestic reform agendas which reduce corruption; promote transparent and accountable institutions; and build open, inclusive economies and societies.

reporting: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland
title: Strengthening Roma minority?s participation in policy and decision making in Ukraine
description:
The realization of the Sustainable Development Goals in Ukraine requires that Roma women and men in Ukraine can live free of poverty and discrimination. Enhancing Roma people?s meaningful participation in regional and local level decision-making will ensur
e that more attention is paid to their needs and policies and services are more effective. This four-year project aims to ensure that Roma women and men have better opportunities and skills to participate in all aspects of decision making within the implem
entation of the regional and local Roma policies. The project will place a special focus on the needs of Roma facing multiple discrimination and on the empowerment of local NGOs and activists.The project will 1) enhance the knowledge of Roma on participati
on in decision making and advocacy 2) enhance the capacities of the regional and local authorities  on Roma inclusion policies 3) empower and activate Roma youth as future change makers 4) raise awareness on the inequalities and forms of discrimination fac
ed by Roma.The project will do this by fostering partnerships between regional administration and Roma NGOS providing capacity development advice and training activities both for NGOs and representativesof authorities training Roma as civic monitors and th
rough organizing media campaigns. The project is implemented in four administrative regions: Kharkiv Odessa Luhansk Donetsk. The last ones have been severely affected by the conflict in East Ukraine. Activities are done only on the territories under the co
ntrol of the Ukrainian Government. The project is implemented by Ukrainian Roma NGO Roma Women Fund Chiricli and Helsinki Deaconess Institute. The project partners are:  Roma Rights Centre (Odessa) Romen (Kharkiv) Roma Center Ugledar (Donetsk) BahtaloDrom 
(Luhansk) Suomen Romaniyhdistys ry the Ukrainian Regional State Administrations in the four regions the Ukrainian Parliament Commissioner for Human Rights and the City of Jyväskylä.

title: Saudi Arabia Environment Sustainability Programme
description: Saudi Arabia is the largest country in West Asia with vast natural resources, diverse and vulnerable ecosystems and biodiversity.  In 2016, the Saudi Government launched an ambitious transformational plan, called Vision 2030 which expresses the Kingdom's long-term goals and expectations and reflects the country’s strengths and capabilities. It includes a sweeping set of programs and reforms to be implemented by 2030. It is built around three themes: A vibrant society, a thriving economy and an ambitious nation. Environment, sustainability and the Sustainable Development Goals are embodied across the three themes.\n\nFollowing the endorsement of the National Environment Strategy in 2018, environment governance is undergoing a profound reform with the ultimate aim of safeguarding the environment and natural resources of the Kingdom and contribute to the achievement of economic prosperity and SDGs. To support such transformation, the Government of Saudi Arabia requested UNEP  to provide the required technical assistance to support the implementation of the environment strategy. The agreement to enter into a strategic partnership with the Government was signed on 19 May 2019 with a total government funding of US $25,256,000 over five years period. Environmental challenges and priorities as well as capacity development needs were elaborated during the preparation of the strategic cooperation agreement and its work plan.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: UkSATSE Liquidity Facility
description: This project was approved in the context of the Bank's response to the COVID-19  pandemic.  To avoid delays to the delivery of this project, the Bank's  President granted a deviation from the ordinary timelines for PSD disclosure,  as contemplated by Section V of the Directive on Access to Information. Details  of the Bank's response to COVID-19, and this deviation, can be found on our  website.  A liquidity facility in the amount of up to EUR 25 million, split  into Tranche 1 (up to EUR 12.5 million, to be committed at signing) and Tranche  2 (up to EUR 12.5 million, to be committed at the Bank's sole discretion), to  support the Ukrainian State Air Traffic Services Enterprise ("UkSATSE", "the  company").  The proceeds of the loan will be used to finance critical liquidity and working  capital needs of the company, thereby providing emergency liquidity support to  mitigate the negative effects of the COVID-19 crisis.  To assist the company with meeting its debt service obligations, the Bank  will also defer principal repayments under the Bank's existing loan to UkSATSE  (BDS 11-310) for the period July 2020-April 2021 in the total amount of EUR  1.089 million.  Tranche 2 of the existing loan will be cancelled to manage the  company's leverage position and in view of resulting changes to the company's  investment priorities triggered by the COVID-19 crisis.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Nibulon WC Loan
description: This project was approved in the context of the Bank's response to the COVID-19  pandemic. To avoid delays to the delivery of this project, the Bank's President  granted a deviation from the ordinary timelines for PSD disclosure, as  contemplated by Section V of the Directive on Access to Information. Details of  the Bank's response to COVID-19, and this deviation, can be found on the Bank's  website.  A senior secured loan of up to USD 27 million (the "loan") to Nibulon LLC  (the "borrower") under the Resilience Framework. The loan will enable Nibulon  LLC to secure sufficient working capital financing for the following seasons  and support in further developing its trading activity in Ukraine amid the  adverse impact of COVID-19 on its business.  The loan will support Nibulon Group's liquidity for trading operations and help  it withstand the COVID19-caused crisis. The operation will ensure that Nibulon  remains committed to developing river transport networks and increasing inland  grain procurement in new rural areas which were part of previous operations  between the Bank and Nibulon Group.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Galnaftogaz Loan IV
description: The provision of a senior loan of up to US$ 35 milion to finance 2020-2022  capital expenditure and working capital needs of JSC "Concern Galnaftogaz"  ("GNG" or the "Company"), an independent distributor of transportation fuels  based in Ukraine.  The Project will focus on the following objectves: (i) working capital to  develop GNG's Farmer Supply Programme; (ii) improvements in GNG's logistics  infrastructure; and (iii) capital expenditure for GNG's fuel stations network,  including the installation of electric vehicles charging stations

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: UGV Project
description: Provision of up to EUR 52 million debt funding to JSC Ukrgasvydobuvannya  ("UGV", the "Company"), a 100% upstream subsidiary of Public Joint Stock  Company "National Joint Stock Company Naftogaz of Ukraine" ("Naftogaz", the  "Parent") to finance the procurement of workover rigs and a package of energy  efficiency investments.  The Project will support the Company to sustain natural gas production from the  UGV's existing fields via increased wells availability by financing a  replacement of inefficient workover rigs procurement. The Project will also  support energy efficiency investments, which will introduce innovative  ORC-based waste heat recovery systems from existing gas turbines.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Novus Retail and Logistics
description: The provision of an up to USD 100 million loan to the Novus supermarket chain  for the expansion of its network of stores, for the upgrade of its logistics  infrastructure with the construction of a logistics centre in Kyiv.  The Project will allow Novus to increase its customer base and scale up its  operations. In addition, the construction of a logistics centre will allow the  Company to increase its centralisation ratio and achieve greater efficiency and  to meet the future demand from an expanded network of stores. These investments  will enhance the Company's operating profile, and should sustain its positive  operating and financial performance.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: RBA Nadezhda Project
description: The provision of an unfunded risk sharing guarantee for the Raiffeisen Bank  Aval, which is organising working capital financing of up to UAH 440 million (€  15 million equivavlent) to Nadezhda Group, an independent Ukrainian wholesale  and retail distributor of liquefied petroleum gas and petroleum products.  The Loan will allow Nadezhda Group to: 1) consolidate and optimise its debt  portfolio, reduce the number of opened short-term credit lines with other  commercial banks; 2) maintain current working capital debt financing level.

title: COVID-19 UNFPA Ukraine: social norms change and gender stereotypes elimination 2020-2023
description:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19
UNFPA has applied to Sida for funding of 15 400 000 SEK to carry out the "Equality springboard: social norms change and gender stereotypes elimination" Project in Ukraine during the period 2020-2023. 

The intervention aims at boosting the process of social norms change and withdrawal from gender stereotypes in education, at work and at home, as well as in the community life. This goal will be achieved by 1) enhancing capacities of the education system to integrate gender sensitive approach; 2) supporting men and boys’ engagement into advancing gender equality at the community level through applying equal distribution of duties in family life and participation in fathers' programs; 3) engaging corporate sector to introduce family friendly gender sensitive approaches, including domestic and gender-based violence prevention practices.  

The intervention’s total budget is 15 900 000 SEK, out of which the organization’s own funding is approximately 494 000 SEK (54 000 USD).
sector_code: Ending violence against women and girls

title: Ukraine EUACI - PHASE II
description:
Overall objective: Reduction of corruption in Ukraine at the national and local level through the empowerment of citizens, the civil society, businesses and state institutions.

Strategic objectives:

Objective 1: Enhanced independence, effectiveness and resilience of anti-corruption institutions functioning within a sound strategic framework.

Objective 2: Reduced corruption at the local level in "Integrity Cities" and in other cities.

Objective 3: Increased awareness of, and engagement in, integrity issues through engagement of the business sector, the civil society and the media.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Green Cities 2 W2 - Khmelnytskyi Solid Waste Project
description: The provision of a senior loan of up to € 28.5 million to Communal Enterprise  "Spetskomuntrans" (the "Company") to finance the rehabilitation and  modernisation of solid waste infrastructure in the City of Khmelnytskyi. The  Project is a part of the Green Cities Framework 2. The facility is designed to  serve as a sector-wide catalyst for addressing environmental challenges at the  city level.  The phase I of the Project will address the City's urgent investment needs with  respect to (i) the rehabilitation of the existing landfill, (ii) the  construction of a new engineered sanitary landfill in compliance with the EU  standards adjacent to the old one, (iii) the acquisition of new landfill  equipment to ensure sustainable operation of the new landfill, and (iv)  improvements of the solid waste collection and transportation systems  co-financed from the City's budget.  The phase II of the Project includes the construction of a new Material  Recovery Facility ("MRF") for non-organic waste and a separate composting  facility for pre-sorted organic waste that will reduce the share of solid waste  going to the landfill by promoting recycling and providing a modern solid waste  management infrastructure with respect to sorting and composting. The Project  will ensure that a long-term, sustainable solid waste management strategy is  properly implemented.

The higher-level objective is to help safeguard Ukraines macroeconomic stability

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: PSEEF: Dnipro Public Buildings EE
description: A senior loan of up to EUR 25 million to the Communal Enterprise "Dniprovska  Municipalna Energoservisna Kompanya", the municipal energy management company,  owned by the city of Dnipro. The loan is expected to be co-financed by up to  EUR 5.5 million investment grant from the Eastern Europe Energy Efficiency and  Environment Partnership (E5P), subject to grant approval by the E5P Assembly of  Contributors. The local contribution of up to EUR 2.5 million will cover  additional energy conservation measures and capital repairs.  The project proceeds will finance a pipeline of works contracts with elements  of an Energy Performance Contract (EnPC") for energy efficiency investments  in 98 public buildings, including 67 kindergartens, 27 schools and 4 outpatient  clinics.  The loan will be a sub-project under the Public Sector Energy Efficiency  Financing Framework, consisting of municipal-guaranteed loans to municipal  energy management companies in Ukraine to facilitate critical improvements in  energy efficiency measures in public buildings in a number of cities across  Ukraine.  The proposed investment will enable the city to finance energy efficiency  measures through EnPCs implemented by private contractors selected by  competitive tender. The investments are expected to result in strong  improvement of buildings' condition through renovation of facilities and  meeting heating requirements, improved comfort level and reliability of  services at kindergartens, schools and clinics, as well as reduction of energy  and maintenance costs of the buildings and decrease of CO2 emissions.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Ukrposhta Logistics Development
description: The provision of a senior sovereign-guaranteed loan of up to €63 million to  Ukrposhta JSC, the national postal operator of Ukraine, consisting of three  tranches:  i Tranche 1 of up to €23 million for the acquisition and equipping of postal  vans to be deployed in rural areas ("Mobile Post Offices")  i Tranche 2 of up to €30 million for the development of modern automated  sorting hubs in the three regional centres and an associated network of  regional sorting depots  i Tranche 3 of up EUR 10 million for the acquisition and equipping of  additional postal vans to complete the program of Mobile Post Office deployment  in rural areas across the country. It is envisaged that Tranche 3 will be  committed at a later date.  The first and third tranches will support the reorganisation of Ukrposhta's  branch network to ensure sustainable provision of modern delivery, retail and  other services to the country's rural population.  The second tranche will help focus on the transformation of Ukrposhta's  logistical model to improve operating efficiency and quality of service in its  delivery business.

reporting: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland
title: DDG/Humanitarian Mine Action in Ukraine
description:
In Ukraine DDG will clear mines and other explosives in the immediate vicinity of the Contact Line in Eastern Ukraine provide risk education to local population and humanitarian workers and assist victims of mines. DDG?s programme will support vulnerable p
opulations affected by mines and Explosive Remnants of War (ERW) and enhance possibilities for them to earn a decent living. Clearance will be conducted in areas that are of central importance in terms of agriculture and infrastructure. The project will pr
omote physical security by removing explosive hazards and thus reducing the number of civilian casualties and accidents caused by mines. It also promotes socioeconomic development by releasing land for income-generating purposes and by facilitating freedom
 of movement. National and local authorities will be supported in their response to the threat posed by explosives. DDG will recruit local personnel including women and thus provide employment in the area. The primary beneficiaries of the project are the c
urrent and returning populations near the conflict zone. Finland will fund DDG's project with 2 million euros during 2021-2025.
sector_code: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war

reporting: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland
title: FRC/ICRC/Humanitarian Mine Action in Ukraine
description:
In Ukraine the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) works with communities in front-line and buffer zones and helps them reduce the risk of mine accidents and other explosive remnants of war. It provides risk education activities supports humani
tarian demining actors and increases the capacity of the Ukrainian Red Cross in humanitarian mine action. Finnish funding is directed towards two rehabilitation centers in Eastern Ukraine. Beneficiaries of these activities include the local population espe
cially the victims of mine accidents and the disabled but also national and regional authorities through capacity building activities. Risk education sessions are also held in schools training children to avoid the danger of explosive devices. Finland supp
orts ICRC?s activities in Ukraine through the Finnish Red Cross with an amount of 500 000 euros during 2021-2025.

title: EBRD SWUK 2 (2020) - Ukraine Municipal Infrastructure Cooperation Account
description:
This is the trust fund between the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) and Sida  to support the municipal infrastructure investment portfolio of the EBRD in Ukraine with the financing for the technical assistance assignments.

The EBRD provides loans across the length and breadth of Ukraine to develop, improve and modernize a wide spectrum of municipal activities, including district heating, water and wastewater, urban transport (fleet renewal, urban roads, metros and e-ticketing), solid waste management and energy efficiency in public and residential buildings, using performance based contracting structures, together with smart solutions.  On the municipal infrastructure front, the EBRD took a non-sovereign lending approach by providing financing directly to municipalities.  

The municipal companies in Ukraine are suffering from underinvestment, inadequate tariff policies and drain of qualified personnel and have very limited internal capacity to prepare and supervise implementation of technically challenging or large-scale investment projects. These critical functions can be carried out by experienced international and local consultants financed from the proposed trust fund. 

The proposed support to the trust fund will allow the Embassy/Sida to continue technical assistance support of critical municipal investments across a range of sub-sectors in Ukraine. The trust fund will maintain the operational model of the existing cooperation between the EBRD and the Embassy/Sida with the assignments being prepared, managed and supervised by the EBRD while the Embassy/Sida will maintain the right to provide prior approval to all eligible assignments. Indicative size of the fund based on the provided pipeline of assignments forecast by the EBRD is 75 MSEK for the coming 5 year period starting in 2021.

title: UKRAINE RECOVERY PROGRAMME
description: The project builds on the successful Ukraine Early Recovery project (EUR 200m; fully allocated), one of the first measures under the EIB Special Action Plan Ukraine providing EUR 3 billion loans in 3 years. This is the second framework loan supporting priority investments in the recovery areas affected by the conflict in the Eastern region of Ukraine. It will also finance basic infrastructure needs of internally displaced population.\n\nHence the project will allow restoring basic services, rehabilitating key infrastructure and creating an enabling environment for population return and economic recovery.

title: UKRAINE URBAN PUBLIC TRANSPORT II
description: Framework loan for the financing of urban public transport investments in midsize and large municipalities in Ukraine. The project will support electric urban public transport schemes that aim at purchasing new rolling stock (trolleybuses, trams, metro coaches and electric buses) or rehabilitating the existing urban public transport infrastructure or extending it with new elements.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: EaP SMEC - OTP Leasing SME Loan
description: A four-year amortising senior unsecured loan of up to €25 million equivalent to  be provided to LLC "OTP Leasing" for on-lending to eligible MSMEs under SME  Competitiveness Programme in Eastern Partnership. The loan will be available  for disbursement as a synthetic UAH and/or euro-denominated facility. In  addition to long-term financing, eligible sub-borrowers will receive technical  assistance funded by the European Union and grant support in the form of  investment incentives upon the completion of their investment projects.  The project will enable the company to finance long-term investments of  Ukrainian MSMEs in upgrading their technology and equipment necessary to meet  EU standards in terms of product quality, health and safety measures and  environmental preservation. At least 80 per cent of all financed sub-leases are  expected to be compliant with EBRD Green Economy Transition (GET) approach.

title: Ukraine Local Empowerment, Accountability and Development Programme Phase II (ULEAD II)
description: The overall objective of Ukraine Local Empowerment Accountability and Development programme phase II (U-LEAD II) is to contribute to further advancement of multilevel governance in Ukraine, which is transparent, accountable and responsive to the needs of the population. \n\nDenmark has supported U-LEAD Phase I since 2016 and the second phase provides continued instrumental support to decentralisation and local government reform.

title: NIR ITP Sustainability Impact Accelerator SIA
description:
Eftersom SIA-programmet har två övergripande mål beskrivs delmålen för dem en i taget. 
Övergripande mål A: Öka kapaciteten hos lokala institutioner i utvecklingsländer att möta internationella hållbarhetsstandarder för infrastrukturprojekt, främst IFC Performance Standards.
Delmål 1a: Lokala institutioner förändrar sin planering/implementering 
Delmål 2a: Infrastrukturprojekten når högre hållbarhetskrav (ex IFC PSs)
Delmål 3a: Hållbar finansiering kan mobiliseras till infrastrukturprojekten 
Underdelmål 1a till samtliga delmål: Förändrad kapacitet i institutioner som får stöd
Input 1a: Erbjuda projektanpassat kapacitetsbyggande stöd till institutioner i DAC-länder som planerar/implementerar infrastrukturinvesteringar 
 
Övergripande mål B: Göra användandet av den svenska resursbasen mer flexibelt och effektivt genom etablerandet av en Kompetensdatabas, samarbete i Team Sweden, samt skapa en Projektdatabas över inkommande förfrågningar om svenskt kapacitetsstöd för att möjliggöra ett datadrivet underlag i utformandet av framtida kapacitetsbyggande verktyg.
Delmål 1b: Svenska expertresurser rekryteras i nya konstellationer
Delmål 2b: Team Swedens gemensamma kompetens nyttjas
Delmål 3b: Team Sweden inkl Sida får en överblick över hur kapacitetsbehoven och efterfrågan ser ut  
Input 1b: Skapa en kompetensdatabas över svenska experter i olika sektorer
Input 2b: Skapa ett samarbete med Team Sweden 
Input 3b: Skapa en projektdatabas över inkommande förfrågningar till Team Sweden om kapacitetsstöd

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Ukraine Road Corridors
description: Provision of a sovereign loan of up to EUR 450 million to Ukraine to be on-lent  to Ukravtodor, the State Road Agency of Ukraine, consisting of three tranches  (the "project"):    * Tranche 1 of up to EUR 100 million to finance the rehabilitation of the  M-05 Kyiv-Odesa road section in Cherkasy region,   * Tranche 2 of up to EUR 160 million to finance the construction of a  northern section of the bypass around the city of Lviv,   * Tranche 3 of up to EUR 190 million to finance the rehabilitation of the  M-05 Kyiv-Odesa road sections in Kirovohrad, Mykolaiv and Odesa regions.  Tranches 1 and 3 aim to support the rehabilitation of strategically important  sections of the M05 Kyiv-Odesa road, which is part of Corridor IX of the  Trans-European Transport Network ("TEN-T") and one of the busiest roads in the  country connecting the capital to the biggest city in the south and the Black  Sea ports, which are a vital logistical hub for freight transport.  Tranche 2 will support the completion of the ring-road around the city of  Lviv, which is located at the intersection of TEN-T Corridors III and V, and  will enable through traffic to bypass the city more effectively improving  travel times and reducing congestion in the city.  The project will also support legal and regulatory reform objectives aimed at  developing a competitive and transparent road construction and maintenance  sector.

reporting: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
title: Kryvyi Rih Industrial Gas LLC
description: Provision of a long-term loan of up to USD 81 million to Kryvyi Rih Industrial  Gas LLC (the "Company"), a Joint Venture with majority ownership by Air  Products & Chemicals Inc., a company registered in the USA. Subject to  finalisation of commercial agreements, the Company will design, construct and  operate an on-site air separation unit (the "Project") to be located in Kryvyi  Rih.  The Project will employ modern, state-of-the-art technology to safely and  reliably produce industrial gases, for ArcelorMittal's Kryvyi Rih steel works  and other customers in Ukraine and beyond.  By replacing existing industrial  gas production on ArcelorMittal's site, the new facility will reduce the annual  energy consumption of the steel plant.

title: IDLO - International Development Law Organisation 2021-2024
description:
IDLO is an intergovernmental organization with a global mandate to advance the rule of law, peace and sustainable development; https://www.idlo.int/. IDLO has applied for 100 MSEK in continued unearmarked flexible financial support from Sida to be used for the implementation of IDLO´s Strategic Plan 2021-2024. 

IDLO is composed of 37 Member Parties. Sweden is member of IDLO since 2017.  IDLO´s mission is to "champion people-centered justice and promote the rule of law to advance sustainable development and help build more peaceful, inclusive and resilient societies". The multilateral organisation collaborates with governments, inter-governmental organizations and civil society organisations and groups to provide technical legal assistance, support capacity development, generate knowledge and advocate for policy change.

IDLO has recently developed the new Strategic Plan (2021-2024) which structures IDLO’s work around two Strategic Goals and six Strategic Objectives based on the commitment to putting people’s needs and human rights at the center of justice systems and making the rule of law a driver of sustainable development. According to IDLO, they strive, through the new strategy, to advance the interdependence and mutually reinforcing connection between human rights, democracy and the rule of law.

The first Strategic Goal (Goal 1) seeks to make justice systems more effective and responsive to people’s needs and help protect their human rights. It builds on IDLO’s expertise in legal empowerment and access to justice (Objective 1), institutional strengthening and reforms (Objective 2), and addressing key justice barriers faced by women and girls (Objective 3). The second Strategic Goal (Goal 2) seeks to leverage the contribution of the rule of law and human rights to peace and sustainable development. It aims to promote inclusive economic development (Objective 4), climate justice and sustainable use of natural resources (Objective 5), and healthy lives and well-being for all (Objective 6). IDLO has also identified four organizational Enablers to strengthen key aspects of the operations to achieve the Strategic Goals and deliver high-quality results.
